comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: I find a Miss Helen Kellogg of Brooklyn, who was a debutante in 1931, and her sister Beatrice was a debutante the next year. That would fit the age about right (if the child above was 2 in 1915, she'd be 18 in 1931). If that's the same girl, she was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris W. Kellogg, and here's her obituary, as Dr. Helen Winthrop Edey, from 1998: www.nytimes.com/1998/09/29/nyregion/dr-helen-winthrop-ede...

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: It all fits.. I think you got it. Morris W. Kellogg and Marie Winthrop married in October, 1910. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20813FA345D16738... He was the founder of a pipe fabrication firm that eventually became today's massive KBR, (Kellogg, Brown & Root). "1901 - Morris W. Kellogg established M. W. Kellogg Company, small pipe fabrication business, in New York City; grew to become world-class engineering firm; led to new technologies that became foundation for petroleum refining, petrochemical processing facilities; 1988 - acquired by Dresser Industries; 1998 - acquired by Halliburton formed Kellogg Brown & Root (engineering, construction subsidiary)." www.businesshistory.com/ind._oil_service.php Blue Book, 1930: Kellogg, Mr. & Mrs. Morris W. 14 E. 72 Miss Helen W. Kellogg
